_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Chem Fluer RMP Executive Summary

The Chem Fluer. Firmchem Chemical Manufacturing Center is

located on an approximately 18 acre industrial site in a

secluded area of Port Newark. The location is bounded to the

East  by Newark Bay, on the South by marshlands and the  New

Jersey  Turnpike, to the West by an over the road  trucking

company terminal, and to the North by a CONRAIL railhead and

new car storage facilities.



The Firmchem Chemical Manufacturing Center produces a

variety of specialty chemicals for the Flavor & Fragrance

industry. A number of our products are manufactured through

chemical processes regulated under the OSHA Process Safety

Management rule (OSHA 1910.119). One of these processes is

also regulated under the EPA Risk Management Program. The

facility  must  also comply with other federal,  state,  and

local  safety  and  environmental regulations, as well  as

internal  company  standards. We conduct business with the

highest priority on the safety and health of our employees,

customers, and the general public, as well as on the

protection of the environment.



The site is regulated under the USEPA RMP rules for use of

one flammable liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) material

Isobutylene (2-Methylpropene or [-Propane, 2-methyl-] CAS

#115-11-7).  Isobutylene is used in one process known as

"DDD".  The isobutylene is used as a reactant in the DDD

manufacturing process. The isobutylene is purchased from

ExxonMobil and received and stored on-site in an industrial

standard LPG trailer designed and operated to comply with

all US Department of Transportation (DOT) safety regulations

and specifications.  The material is onsite for about 12

weeks or about 23% of the year.



The storage tank is located in an isolated area of the plant

and in plant structures including a 500,000-gallon firewater

tank, and three process buildings 55 feet high provide a

substantial buffer between the storage area and the plant

fenceline on three sid

es. To the rear there is approximately

one thousand feet of undeveloped land to the shore of Newark

Bay. Catastrophic failure of the tank due to physical impact

or impingement by fire are the two primary worse-case loss

scenarios. All chemical processing facilities in the area of

the isobutylene tank are protected by automatic sprinkler or

deluge systems, and a high pressure water cannon is in the

immediate vicinity of the isobutylene tank holding area. The

tank is protected by controlling traffic in the area and by

use of concrete jersey barriers, which are ringed around the

tank.   The   Newark Fire Department is a paid force

specializing in industrial facilities. The typical response

time for fires in the area is about 5 to 10 minutes.



The facility's process safety management program is

organized in a manner consistent with the OSHA PSM rule. The

accident prevention program requirements of RMP closely

follow the programs in place to comply with PSM. These

programs help to ensure  the  safe operation and maintenance

of our  chemical processes,  and  prevent  and mitigate

potential  accidents involving  regulated  and  other

hazardous  chemicals.  Key features of the Firmchem accident

prevention program are described below.



Process Safety information of all types is gathered and

retained in designated locations. Examples include MSDS's,

in-house reactivity and stability data, chemical

compatibility matrices, process chemistry and hazards,

P&IDs, electrical classification, equipment drawings and

specifications, and interlock descriptions. This information

is available for process hazard analyses and the development

of other process safety elements.



Process hazard analyses (PHA's) are conducted on both PSM

regulated and non-regulated processes, with the level of

detail commensurate with the hazards. PHA's utilize both

HAZOP and What-if techniques. Multidisciplinary PHA teams

are assembled, including a trained team leader, engin

eering,

research and development, production supervision and

production operators. A tracking system for recommendations

is used to ensure recommendations are addressed.

Revalidations are initiated at intervals of five years or

less.



Batch procedures are used extensively by operators as step-by-

step instructions in the regulated multi-purpose batch

processes. These procedures are carefully developed from

pertinent process safety information. Where possible,

sophisticated computer programming is applied to run the

operations, which improves process reliability, quality, and

safety. This allows production personnel to focus on

troubleshooting and other high level tasks.



Personnel operating chemical processes have been trained in

their job tasks and responsibilities by working side-by-side

with more experienced operators, use of outside training

materials, and consultation with supervisory personnel.

Supervision evaluates the performance of employees to

determine when they are prepared to operate independently.

Safe work practices, such as equipment release,

lockout/tagout, confined space entry, have been developed.

These are occasionally reviewed and updated as needed.



A fully qualified maintenance staff performs repairs and

inspections on equipment and instrumentation used in

regulated chemical processes, using manufacturers' or

internal procedures. Where specialized skills or

certifications are needed, appropriate outside crafts are

used. A system has been developed to define PSM-critical

equipment, to ensure designated equipment is maintained at

the highest integrity level. A computerized maintenance

system has been installed to manage maintenance activities

and records retention.



Firchem has instituted a management of change procedure to

ensure changes to equipment, procedures, etc. are evaluated

for safety implications, properly authorized and documented.

Affected personnel review documentation of process changes

that

affect their work area. The procedure has mechanisms to

ensure that process safety information affected by a process

change is properly updated.



Pre-startup safety reviews are conducted on new and

modification projects to ensure that these projects are

constructed per design and safe to operate.



Compliance auditing of Firmchem's process safety management

programs is performed at least every three years.

Recommendations arising from the audit and their resolutions

are documented and retained, as specified.



Firmchem has a procedure in place to investigate all

accidents resulting in injury and incidents with serious

potential consequences. Several employees have been trained

in incident investigation, and these people are used as

investigation team leaders. Investigations are designed to

identify root causes of incidents, and recommendations to

prevent recurrence. Written reports are prepared and

distributed for review by affected personnel, and

recommendations monitored until completed.



Employee participation is addressed in several ways. First

line production employees are required participants in

process hazard analyses of regulated processes, and they are

also present in most non-regulated PHA's. Employees are also

encouraged to participate in operator training, safety

committee, review of batch operating procedures, and in the

development of other elements of the process safety program.



The facility has established procedures and permits to

manage hot work.



Firmchem uses a variety of outside contractors, and selects

contractors based on a variety of characteristics including

cost, reliability, quality, and safe work. Employee contacts

coordinate contractor training, including potential hazards

and emergency evacuation procedures.



Our facility has experienced substantial growth over the

last few years, and with that growth has made significant

efforts to further enhance the safe manufacture of our

products. Our com

mitment is to continue to be manufactured

safely and reliably, and to protect our employees,

community, and environment.
